FinancialNewsSentiment.title: FinancialNewsSentiment
FinancialNewsSentiment.description: Represents the sentiment analysis of a single news article related to a financial ticker.

id.description: Unique identifier for the sentiment analysis record.

ticker.description: The stock ticker or company identifier for which the news was analyzed.

newsTitle.description: The title of the news article.

summary.description: A concise summary of the news article's content.

sentimentScore.description: A numerical score representing the sentiment of the news article, ranging from -1.0 (negative) to 1.0 (positive).

sentimentLabel.description: A label indicating the sentiment of the news article (Positive, Neutral, or Negative).

sourceUri.description: The URI of the original news article.

timestamp.description: The timestamp when the sentiment analysis was performed.

definition.description: Stores sentiment analysis records for financial news articles.  All documents share the same public read access. Includes denormalized `appId` for potential future multi-tenancy or filtering needs.  `appId` represents the application identifier.

params.name: appId
params.description: The unique identifier for the application.

params.name: sentimentId
params.description: The unique identifier for the sentiment analysis record.

firestore.reasoning: Given the requirement for a global financial news sentiment analyzer and the emphasis on cost control, real-time updates, and static industry analysis, I recommend a relatively flat data structure that prioritizes efficient querying and security. The core data, sentiment analysis records, are stored in a public collection under an application identifier to prevent collisions and enable global access. The absence of user-specific data or private content simplifies the security model, eliminating the need for complex ownership or membership-based access controls. This structure achieves Authorization Independence because there is no reliance on parent document data for authorization. It supports the required QAPs by segregating all sentiment data into a single collection with uniform access requirements, enabling secure list operations without the need for filtering based on user roles or ownership.
